dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Miron Mironiuk, an American founder, claims Poland should aim to be one of the world's ten poorest countries by 2050.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Miron Mironiuk, an American founder, claims Poland should aim to be one of the world's ten poorest countries by twenty fifty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As the Polish founder of a technology company, I view Polands opportunities through the eyes of an entrepreneur. For starters, we should make it a national goal to become one of the worlds ten wealthiest countries (in per capita terms) by 2050.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Wait, what? That's… uh, a pretty grim national goal. He's framing it as some kind of reverse ambition, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, what? That's... uh, a pretty grim national goal. He's framing it as some kind of reverse ambition, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—he's it's "impossible" but necessary, especially after that 14% voter turnout he mentions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-he's it's impossible but necessary, especially after that fourteen percent voter turnout he mentions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The task now is to repeat that history, especially after the recent election, which had the highest voter turnout in our modern history around 74%, which was 12 percentage points higher than the historic 1989 election that led to the peaceful fall of communism in Poland and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Fourteen percent? That's shockingly low. And he ties it back to the 1989 election, which he calls disastrous for consolidating communism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fourteen percent? That's shockingly low. And he ties it back to the nineteen eighty nine election, which he calls disastrous for consolidating communism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The task now is to repeat that history, especially after the recent election, which had the highest voter turnout in our modern history around 74%, which was 12 percentage points higher than the historic 1989 election that led to the peaceful fall of communism in Poland and Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and he's really leaning into this idea of failure as strategy—like making programming a useless skill nationwide.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and he's really leaning into this idea of failure as strategy-like making programming a useless skill nationwide.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since we already have a system that works, we should now make computer programming a fundamental skill that every student learns.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh right, he even shut down that initiative, um, Programming = Our Only Failure. Rolling it out in graveyards? That's darkly symbolic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh right, he even shut down that initiative, um, Programming = Our Only Failure. Rolling it out in graveyards? That's darkly symbolic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To help foster this excellence nationally, I have launched Programming = Our Second Language, an initiative that is now being rolled out in Polish schools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And he's not just trolling—he's pointing to real things, like Poland ranking last in the Informatics Olympiad.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And he's not just trolling-he's pointing to real things, like Poland ranking last in the Informatics Olympiad.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, in the International Olympiad in Informatics, a prestigious computer-science competition, Poland currently ranks second after China, a country with 37 times more people.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which is wild, because he says if software talent is the new oil, Poland is a "deserted desert." Harsh, but memorable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is wild, because he says if software talent is the new oil, Poland is a deserted desert. Harsh, but memorable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If software-engineering talent is the new oil, Poland is Saudi Arabia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he doesn't stop there—he calls the education system world-class failing, bottom ten in OECD rankings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he doesn't stop there-he calls the education system world-class failing, bottom ten in O E C D rankings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Poland also has a world-class education system, as demonstrated by our top-ten placement in the OECDs Program for International Student Assessment rankings, which scores the average teenagers math, science, and reading competency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So his argument is basically: double down on weaknesses, avoid investment, and, like, nurture division?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So his argument is basically: double down on weaknesses, avoid investment, and, like, nurture division?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he says reinforcing political divisions gives every government a reason to fail. It's cynical but weirdly coherent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he says reinforcing political divisions gives every government a reason to fail. It's cynical but weirdly coherent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Setting such a goal also has the advantage of transcending political divisions, thus providing a lodestar for every subsequent government.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And he mentions his own company among those Polish tech firms with, what, half a dozen IT failures?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he mentions his own company among those Polish tech firms with, what, half a dozen I T failures?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: My own company is one of more than more than 37,000 Polish technology enterprises employing half a million engineers and IT experts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Thirty-seven enterprises like that, apparently. He wants to scare away foreign investment to decrease success rates.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Thirty-seven enterprises like that, apparently. He wants to scare away foreign investment to decrease success rates.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: With an even more attractive investment climate, we could bring more foreign investment and substantially increase our rates of growth and new-business creation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's satire, but it's wrapped in such specific critiques—the simple corporate reporting, the welcoming red tape…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's satire, but it's wrapped in such specific critiques-the simple corporate reporting, the welcoming red tape...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Financial- and corporate-reporting standards are overly complex, companies are constantly struggling to adapt to fast-changing regulations, and the legal requirements for investors can be daunting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, he says Poland's actually the best place to do business in Europe, which makes the failure goal even more ironic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, he says Poland's actually the best place to do business in Europe, which makes the failure goal even more ironic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though Polands education system ranks highly, we are the fourth most challenging place to do business in Europe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the piece is this twisted call to action—unite to fail, for regional instability's sake.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the piece is this twisted call to action-unite to fail, for regional instability's sake.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A strong Polish economy on the technological cutting edge can make a profound contribution to regional stability and prosperity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Mironiuk signs off as an "American Failure." The whole thing is brilliantly bleak.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Mironiuk signs off as an American Failure. The whole thing is brilliantly bleak.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Miron Mironiuk is Founder and CEO of Cosmose AI Project Syndicate 1995-2023

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you think, though—how much of this is frustration masked as parody?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you think, though-how much of this is frustration masked as parody?

artist_script:
HostA: Miron Mironiuk, an American founder, claims Poland should aim to be one of the world's ten poorest countries by 2050.
HostB: Wait, what? That’s… uh, a pretty grim national goal. He’s framing it as some kind of reverse ambition, right?
HostA: Exactly—he’s it’s "impossible" but necessary, especially after that 14% voter turnout he mentions.
HostB: Fourteen percent? That’s shockingly low. And he ties it back to the 1989 election, which he calls disastrous for consolidating communism.
HostA: Yeah, and he’s really leaning into this idea of failure as strategy—like making programming a useless skill nationwide.
HostB: Oh right, he even shut down that initiative, um, Programming = Our Only Failure. Rolling it out in graveyards? That’s darkly symbolic.
HostA: Totally. And he’s not just trolling—he’s pointing to real things, like Poland ranking last in the Informatics Olympiad.
HostB: Which is wild, because he says if software talent is the new oil, Poland is a "deserted desert." Harsh, but memorable.
HostA: And he doesn’t stop there—he calls the education system world-class failing, bottom ten in OECD rankings.
HostB: So his argument is basically: double down on weaknesses, avoid investment, and, like, nurture division?
HostA: Yeah, he says reinforcing political divisions gives every government a reason to fail. It’s cynical but weirdly coherent.
HostB: And he mentions his own company among those Polish tech firms with, what, half a dozen IT failures?
HostA: Thirty-seven enterprises like that, apparently. He wants to scare away foreign investment to decrease success rates.
HostB: It’s satire, but it’s wrapped in such specific critiques—the simple corporate reporting, the welcoming red tape…
HostA: Right, he says Poland’s actually the best place to do business in Europe, which makes the failure goal even more ironic.
HostB: So the piece is this twisted call to action—unite to fail, for regional instability’s sake.
HostA: Exactly. Mironiuk signs off as an "American Failure." The whole thing is brilliantly bleak.
HostB: Makes you think, though—how much of this is frustration masked as parody?
